qas.question: On what principle did the Ancient Greeks first think was best for governance?
According to Plato, who was above the law?
What type of kingdom was purported by Plato?
Under what rule did Aristotle believe a nation should be led?
To what did Plato compare a government that follows laws?
What form of government did the Greeks think was second only to democracy?
Who advocated ruled by a philosopher king who was subject to the law?
Who did Plato hope would be subject to the established laws?
Who did Aristotle envision ruling a benevolent monarchy?

context: In the West, the ancient Greeks initially regarded the best form of government as <a0_0><b5_0>rule by the best men<b5_0/><a0_0/>. <b6_0>Plato<b6_0/> advocated a <a2_0>benevolent monarchy<a2_0/> ruled by an idealized <b8_0>philosopher <a1_0>king<a1_0/>,<b8_0/> who was above the law. Plato nevertheless hoped that <b7_0>the best men<b7_0/> would be good at respecting established laws, explaining that "Where the law is subject to some other authority and has none of its own, the collapse of the state, in my view, is not far off; but if law is the master of the government and the government is its <a4_0>slave<a4_0/>, then the situation is full of promise and men enjoy all the blessings that the gods shower on a state." More than Plato attempted to do, Aristotle flatly opposed letting the highest officials wield power beyond guarding and serving the laws.
